segment.source: Windows PE (WinPE)
segment.target: Windows PE (WinPE)

segment.source: Windows PE (WinPE)
segment.target: Windows PE (WinPE)

segment.source: Windows PE (WinPE)
segment.target: Windows PE (WinPE)

segment.source: Windows PE (WinPE) for Windows 10 is a small operating system used to install, deploy, and repair Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, and other Windows operating systems.
segment.target: Windows PE (WinPE) for Windows 10 is a small operating system used to install, deploy, and repair Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, and other Windows operating systems.

segment.source: From Windows PE, you can:
segment.target: From Windows PE, you can:

segment.source: Set up your hard drive before installing Windows.
segment.target: Set up your hard drive before installing Windows.

segment.source: Install Windows by using apps or scripts from a network or a local drive.
segment.target: Install Windows by using apps or scripts from a network or a local drive.

segment.source: Capture and apply Windows images.
segment.target: Capture and apply Windows images.

segment.source: Modify the Windows operating system while it's not running.
segment.target: Modify the Windows operating system while it's not running.

segment.source: Set up automatic recovery tools.
segment.target: Set up automatic recovery tools.

segment.source: Recover data from unbootable devices.
segment.target: Recover data from unbootable devices.

segment.source: Add your own custom shell or GUI to automate these kinds of tasks.
segment.target: Add your own custom shell or GUI to automate these kinds of tasks.

segment.source: windows pe command-line
segment.target: windows pe command-line

segment.source: Where do I download it?
segment.target: Where do I download it?

segment.source: To get Windows PE, use the installer built into the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK).
segment.target: To get Windows PE, use the installer built into the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK).

segment.source: For more info, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive, WinPE: Create a Boot CD, DVD, ISO, or VHD, or see the Demo: Installing Windows PE on a USB Drive.
segment.target: For more info, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive, WinPE: Create a Boot CD, DVD, ISO, or VHD, or see the Demo: Installing Windows PE on a USB Drive.

segment.source: Support for many Windows features
segment.target: Support for many Windows features

segment.source: Windows PE runs the Windows command line environment, and supports these Windows features:
segment.target: Windows PE runs the Windows command line environment, and supports these Windows features:

segment.source: Batch files and scripts, including support for Windows Script Host (WSH), and ActiveX Data Objects (ADO), and optional support for PowerShell.
segment.target: Batch files and scripts, including support for Windows Script Host (WSH), and ActiveX Data Objects (ADO), and optional support for PowerShell.

segment.source: Applications, including Win32 application programming interfaces (APIs) and optional support for HTML Applications (HTA).
segment.target: Applications, including Win32 application programming interfaces (APIs) and optional support for HTML Applications (HTA).

segment.source: Drivers, including a generic set of drivers that can run networking, graphics, and mass storage devices.
segment.target: Drivers, including a generic set of drivers that can run networking, graphics, and mass storage devices.

segment.source: Image capturing and servicing, including Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM).
segment.target: Image capturing and servicing, including Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM).

segment.source: Networking, including connecting to file servers using TCP/IP and NetBIOS over TCP/IP via LAN.
segment.target: Networking, including connecting to file servers using TCP/IP and NetBIOS over TCP/IP via LAN.

segment.source: Storage, including NTFS, DiskPart, and BCDBoot.
segment.target: Storage, including NTFS, DiskPart, and BCDBoot.

segment.source: Security tools, including optional support for BitLocker and the Trusted Platform Module (TPM), Secure Boot, and other tools.
segment.target: Security tools, including optional support for BitLocker and the Trusted Platform Module (TPM), Secure Boot, and other tools.

segment.source: Hyper-V, including VHD files, mouse integration, mass storage and network drivers that allow Windows PE to run in a hypervisor.
segment.target: Hyper-V, including VHD files, mouse integration, mass storage and network drivers that allow Windows PE to run in a hypervisor.

segment.source: Hardware requirements
segment.target: Hardware requirements

segment.source: Windows PE has the same requirements as Windows with these exceptions:
segment.target: Windows PE has the same requirements as Windows with these exceptions:

segment.source: No hard drive is required.
segment.target: No hard drive is required.

segment.source: You can run Windows PE entirely from memory.
segment.target: You can run Windows PE entirely from memory.

segment.source: The base version requires only 512MB of memory.
segment.target: The base version requires only 512MB of memory.

segment.source: (If you add drivers, packages, or apps, you'll need more memory.)
segment.target: (If you add drivers, packages, or apps, you'll need more memory.)

segment.source: In order to boot Windows PE directly from memory (also known as RAM disk boot), a contiguous portion of physical memory (RAM) which can hold the entire Windows PE (WIM) image must be available.
segment.target: In order to boot Windows PE directly from memory (also known as RAM disk boot), a contiguous portion of physical memory (RAM) which can hold the entire Windows PE (WIM) image must be available.

segment.source: To optimize memory use, manufacturers should ensure that their firmware reserves memory locations either at the beginning or at the end of the physical memory address space.
segment.target: To optimize memory use, manufacturers should ensure that their firmware reserves memory locations either at the beginning or at the end of the physical memory address space.

segment.source: The 32-bit version of Windows PE can boot 32-bit UEFI and BIOS PCs, and 64-bit BIOS PCs.
segment.target: The 32-bit version of Windows PE can boot 32-bit UEFI and BIOS PCs, and 64-bit BIOS PCs.

segment.source: The 64-bit version of Windows PE can boot 64-bit UEFI and BIOS PCs.
segment.target: The 64-bit version of Windows PE can boot 64-bit UEFI and BIOS PCs.

segment.source: Limitations
segment.target: Limitations

segment.source: Windows PE is not a general-purpose operating system.
segment.target: Windows PE is not a general-purpose operating system.

segment.source: It may not be used for any purpose other than deployment and recovery.
segment.target: It may not be used for any purpose other than deployment and recovery.

segment.source: It should not be used as a thin client or an embedded operating system.
segment.target: It should not be used as a thin client or an embedded operating system.

segment.source: There are other Microsoft products, such as Windows Embedded CE, which may be used for these purposes.
segment.target: There are other Microsoft products, such as Windows Embedded CE, which may be used for these purposes.

segment.source: To prevent its use as a production operating system, Windows PE automatically stops running the shell and restarts after 72 hours of continuous use.
segment.target: To prevent its use as a production operating system, Windows PE automatically stops running the shell and restarts after 72 hours of continuous use.

segment.source: This period is not configurable.
segment.target: This period is not configurable.

segment.source: When Windows PE reboots, all changes are lost, including changes to drivers, drive letters, and the Windows PE registry.
segment.target: When Windows PE reboots, all changes are lost, including changes to drivers, drive letters, and the Windows PE registry.

segment.source: To make lasting changes, see WinPE: Mount and Customize.
segment.target: To make lasting changes, see WinPE: Mount and Customize.

segment.source: The default Windows PE installation uses the FAT32 file format, which poses its own limitations, including a maximum 4GB file size and maximum 32GB drive size.
segment.target: The default Windows PE installation uses the FAT32 file format, which poses its own limitations, including a maximum 4GB file size and maximum 32GB drive size.

segment.source: To learn more, see WinPE: Use a single USB key for WinPE and a WIM file (.wim).
segment.target: To learn more, see WinPE: Use a single USB key for WinPE and a WIM file (.wim).

segment.source: Windows PE does not support any of the following:
segment.target: Windows PE does not support any of the following:

segment.source: File server or Terminal Server use.
segment.target: File server or Terminal Server use.

segment.source: Joining to a network domain.
segment.target: Joining to a network domain.

segment.source: Connecting to an IPv4 network from Windows PE on an IPv6 network.
segment.target: Connecting to an IPv4 network from Windows PE on an IPv6 network.

segment.source: Remote Desktop.
segment.target: Remote Desktop.

segment.source: .MSI installation files.
segment.target: .MSI installation files.

segment.source: Booting from a path that contains non-English characters.
segment.target: Booting from a path that contains non-English characters.

segment.source: Running 64-bit apps on the 32-bit version of Windows PE.
segment.target: Running 64-bit apps on the 32-bit version of Windows PE.

segment.source: Adding bundled app packages through DISM (.appxbundle packages).
segment.target: Adding bundled app packages through DISM (.appxbundle packages).

segment.source: Note In general, use the latest version of WinPE to deploy Windows.
segment.target: Note In general, use the latest version of WinPE to deploy Windows.

segment.source: If you are using customized WinPE for Windows 10 images, you may prefer to continue using your existing Windows PE image and run the latest version of DISM from a network location.
segment.target: If you are using customized WinPE for Windows 10 images, you may prefer to continue using your existing Windows PE image and run the latest version of DISM from a network location.

segment.source: To learn more, see Copy DISM to Another Computer.
segment.target: To learn more, see Copy DISM to Another Computer.

segment.source: Notes on running Windows Setup in Windows PE:
segment.target: Notes on running Windows Setup in Windows PE:

segment.source: You can use the 32-bit versions of Windows PE and Windows Setup to install 64-bit versions of Windows.
segment.target: You can use the 32-bit versions of Windows PE and Windows Setup to install 64-bit versions of Windows.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments.

segment.source: Although Windows PE supports dynamic disks, Windows Setup does not.
segment.target: Although Windows PE supports dynamic disks, Windows Setup does not.

segment.source: If you install Windows to a dynamic disk created in Windows PE, the dynamic disks won't be available in Windows.
segment.target: If you install Windows to a dynamic disk created in Windows PE, the dynamic disks won't be available in Windows.

segment.source: For UEFI-based PCs that support both UEFI and legacy BIOS modes, Windows PE needs to be booted in the correct mode in order to correctly install Windows.
segment.target: For UEFI-based PCs that support both UEFI and legacy BIOS modes, Windows PE needs to be booted in the correct mode in order to correctly install Windows.

segment.source: For more info, see WinPE: Boot in UEFI or legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more info, see WinPE: Boot in UEFI or legacy BIOS mode.
